text: I found out I was pregnant in the
downstairs deliver McDonald's a week
before had been complaining / boasting
about how big my boobs are God and how
bloated I felt totally naively it hadn't
crossed my mind I could possibly be
pregnant
I hadn't had sex for months and my
periods had been irregular since I'd
come off the implant but after my buddy
brought up joking me the possibility
planted itself in my brain and it's that
they're worrying away as soon as I peed
on my stick it said pregnant like I was
super super super pregnant almost
instantly I was very keenly aware of a
little beam inside my belly I had been
my entire body and brain had found a new
focus and I couldn't stop thinking about
the beam inside my belly it's amazing
what the stick covered in pee can do
and the sacred and totally glorious it
felt to know you made a tiny little life
and it was growing day by day in your
body the thought that just kept running
through my brain was I hope this being
is small enough to come out because I
wasn't ready in no fit state to provide
the sort of life I want to give my baby
I told only a few people my flatmate who
came to watch me pee on my second stick
my boss who let me take the time off
work and who convinced me to tell my mom
and the boy
an ex-boyfriend still very much on the
scene those are the tricky emotional
conversations
initially I planned not to tell either
of them but I'm pleased I let them in I
needed help to pick up the pieces
thankfully the process was quick an
emergency appointment with the doctor
for a referral and appointment the next
day for consultation and treatment I
went with my mum we're very close but
we've never spoken about sex so sitting
in an abortion clinic was a pretty big
step for us abortion such an ugly word
they turn the screen away from me during
the ultrasound my being was too big for
the pill it was three months big and
needed to be taken out surgically
another one that sticks in the throat
walking into the room for the procedure
I was struck by how clinical the whole
thing felt I don't know what I was
expecting but the setup very
intimidating and very serious it was a
small-scale operating theatre with
bright lights a table and a rather
gruesome set of stirrups the surgeon was
a man the anesthetist - I was quickly
maneuvered into position and knocked
down it didn't feel like a place for
helping women in their hour of need felt
like a conveyor belt
one image really sticks in my mind a
memory that I can't fully trust but is
so visually complete and must have come
from somewhere of a hazard sign and
abend for human waste I really hope my
pendant gonna bin but it must have done
with all the other beans from all the
other women and girls who couldn't and
wouldn't have a child I came to in a
room filled with armchairs occupied by
other sad and broken women and I was
very keenly aware that I had lost
something something I was only aware of
for a very short time but that I was
going to miss terribly and I was in such
pain the next few months passed as a
series of internal paddles totally
giving in to grief and sadness versus
pretending to be fine I remember a meal
out with some of my closest friends
everyone was chatting away talking about
boys and dates and jobs and one of my
friends was like what's new with you
what's the Goss and I just burst into
tears because the biggest thing that had
happened to me I didn't feel like a
chair my dad he is so proud of
everything I do beats conservative and
grew up in a time when abortions were
illegal and nice Carlton get pregnant I
know it'd devastate him
so I keep it a secret and I carry that
shame around why should we still feel
shame I have never regretted my decision
it was a hundred percent the right thing
to do for me but the secrecy surrounding
abortion a word made so ugly no one dare
utter it the secrecy is brutal and
crushing six months on I feel stronger
less prone to random spots of Tears I've
tried purposefully not to think about
when this beam would have been born but
I suppose it would have been about now
and that does make me sad as to seeing
mothers with their little ones dad's
tomb and I know that I will never be
able to look at a sonogram until it's
over baby I'm ready death
you
